statements.statement: A few heavy smoke days from prescribed fires are better than constant, less smoky days over several months.
Dealing with frequent, mild smoke from prescribed fires is better than facing the dangers of heavy wildfire smoke.
Even a little smoke makes it hard to breathe.
I’m fine with a bit of smoke from prescribed fires here and there if it means my family and home are safer.
Fewer days with more smoke are better than a lot of days with less smoke.
I don’t care about how often prescribed burns are burned because I don’t want a big wildfire nearby.
Any prescribed fire is good, so I don’t care how often they burn or how much smoke they produce.
I’m fine with either high or low frequency smoke, just don’t burn near schools or hospitals.
More frequent prescribed burns are worth it if they mean avoiding catastrophic wildfires.
The thickness of smoke is more important than how often smoke happens.
There’s no such thing as ‘safe smoke,’ no matter how often or how intense.
I trust prescribed fire managers from state agencies to manage prescribed fires responsibly.
Prescribed fire managers prioritize meeting acreage targets over protecting the public from smoke.
The state government often fails to listen when prescribed fire smoke impacts rural communities.
State agencies are doing the best they can to manage prescribed fires under tough conditions.
Prescribed fires rarely turn into wildfires.
There needs to be more transparency from state agencies about when and why they use prescribed fires.
State agencies act in the public’s interest, even if they make mistakes.
The public should have more say in when and where state agencies use prescribed fires.
It’s hard to trust state agencies when prescribed fires seem to happen with no warning.
Private landowners who use prescribed fires on their own land are more careful than state agencies.
Prescribed burn associations are just as trustworthy as state agencies to manage prescribed fires responsibly.
I don't trust private landowners to consider how their prescribed fires affect my health.
Prescribed burn associations are more transparent about their burns than state agencies in my area.
Prescribed fire managers and people like me want the same thing: healthy forests and safe communities.
Prescribed fire managers don’t understand what matters most to local residents.
Prescribed fire managers need to consider how smoke affects families and vulnerable groups.
There’s a disconnect between public values and the priorities of prescribed fire managers.
I support prescribed burning because it helps maintain healthy wildlife habitat.
Prescribed fire managers care about wildlife just as much as I do.
I have heard that fires are good for wildlife, but I’ve seen animals flee from smoke and flames.
Prescribed fires on public lands should prioritize protecting wildlife, not just reducing wildfire risk.
Prescribed fires bring back birds, deer, and other species I care about.
Keeping people healthy should be the top priority, even if it means prescribed burning less often.
Some smoke from prescribed fires may be worth it if it prevents even worse health impacts from wildfires.
Prescribed fires help reduce risks for firefighters during wildfire season.
Protecting wildland firefighter lives is just as important as protecting forests.
I’ve seen prescribed fires protect my community from wildfires.
Wildfire smoke made me sick, and I now support anything that reduces the risk of smoke exposure from any kind of fire.
I’ve had positive experiences with prescribed fires increasing flowering plants.
A wildfire came too close to my home, and now I see prescribed fires very differently.
I grew up around prescribed fires, it’s just part of life here.
I’ve never had a bad experience with any fire, and I don’t see what the big deal is.
My neighborhood still smells like smoke for days after a prescribed fire, and it’s frustrating.
A wildfire came too close to my property, and I now wish more prescribed fires had been done.
Prescribed fires make the land greener, healthier, and better for wildlife.
I respect the reasons for burning, even if I don’t like the smoke.
